If we use the filtro function with coefficients A=0 and B=ones(10,1)/10 to filter the input signal x, we would expect the output y to start at 1/10 for t=1 and increase by 1/10 for each subsequent time step, as we discussed earlier. Therefore, the first 30 samples of the output y would be:

y(1) = 1/10
y(2) = 2/10
y(3) = 3/10
y(4) = 4/10
y(5) = 5/10
y(6) = 6/10
y(7) = 7/10
y(8) = 8/10
y(9) = 9/10
y(10) = 1
y(11) = 1.1
y(12) = 1.2
y(13) = 1.3
y(14) = 1.4
y(15) = 1.5
y(16) = 1.6
y(17) = 1.7
y(18) = 1.8
y(19) = 1.9
y(20) = 2
y(21) = 2.1
y(22) = 2.2
y(23) = 2.3
y(24) = 2.4
y(25) = 2.5
y(26) = 2.6
y(27) = 2.7
y(28) = 2.8
y(29) = 2.9
y(30) = 3

These values reflect the effect of the filter on the input signal x, which is a square wave of amplitude 1 that switches between -1 and 1 every second. The filter smooths out the transitions between the two levels of the square wave, resulting in a gradually increasing output y that starts at 1/10 and reaches a maximum of 3 after 30 samples.
